text: it's the hardest thing to do in sports
hitting a round ball with a round bag
squarely so hard that failing seven out
of ten times is still good enough to
land in like a million dollar contract
good eyesight back good concentration
years of practice
excellent reaction a batter needs it all
armed with only a wooden stick he has
less than a quarter of a second to see
the pitch judge its speed and location
decide what to do and then swing while
skill and consistency are paramount
the fate of the ball has a lot to do
with physics as well
a 90 mile an hour fastball is in flight
impact is set to occur in 400
milliseconds the first 100 milliseconds
are needed for the batter's eye to see
the ball and send an image to the brain
another 75 milliseconds is needed for
the brain to gauge speed location of the
pitch at 50 milliseconds more to decide
where to swing the bat with 165
milliseconds still remaining to impact
the brain signals the swing to begin if
it's as little as 7 milliseconds too
early or too late
the ball will sail foul after contact a
[Music]
2-pound bat traveling at 80 miles per
hour and strike the ball with a force of
up to 9 horsepower for each extra mile
per hour generated in backswing there is
potential for an extra seven and a half
feet in flight distance for the faster
he swings the farther ball will go
that ball collision takes just 1/1000 of
a second to occur if all goes right
contact takes place within 1/8 of an
inch of the bat sweet spot a small node
roughly six and a half inches in the end
of the bat this minimizes vibration and
maximizes energy transfer to the ball if
the ball misses the sweet spot a weaker
hit is guaranteed along with a painful
sting to the batter's hands and forearms
[Music]
at optimal in fact a force of over 8,000
pounds will compress the ball to almost
half its diameter if then rebounds off
the bat it begins accelerating to the
110 miles an hour it needs to travel
over 400 feet understanding the physics
and physiology of hitting shows just how
complex the task really is baseball
physicist Robert Adair dubs it clearly
impossible
a superhuman feat though others would
simply call it Ruthie
